docs.lead_paragraph: People who meditate regularly appear to undergo changes in parts of the brain that handle perception and attentiveness, a new study suggests. The study sample is small, and it is unclear what the changes may mean, but researchers said that when they compared M.R.I. scans of people who meditated with those of people who did not, they found more gray matter in the frontal cortexes of those who meditate.

headline.main: When Mindful Awareness Goes to Your Head

docs.abstract: Dr Sara W Lazar of Massachusetts General Hospital leads research on impact of moderate amounts of meditation on brain; research, which is published in journal NeuroReport, finds larger frontal cortex in those who meditate; study could not definitively link more brain mass to meditation; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: People who meditate regularly appear to undergo changes in parts of the brain that handle perception and attentiveness.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Cold weather can cause a cold. THE FACTS -- Can you catch a cold from catching a chill? Common wisdom says yes, but scientists have for years insisted that colds are more common in the winter largely because the weather drives people indoors, allowing germs to jump easily from one person to the next.
docs.snippet: A few studies have provided scientific evidence that a chill won't cause a cold, but perhaps the answer is not so clear cut.

docs.lead_paragraph: The lack of emotional care given to infants in some Romanian and Russian orphanages has provided researchers an opportunity to study the hormonal basis of the mother-child bond. Researchers led by Seth D. Pollak of the University of Wisconsin have found that these children, even three and a half years after adoption into Wisconsin families, produce two critical hormones in a different pattern from children with traditional upbringings.
docs.abstract: Dr Seth D Pollak of University of Wisconsin leads study on impact of hormones oxytocin and vasopressin in orphaned children; research, which is published in journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, comes from study of Romanian orphans who had been adopted by Wisconsin families; find that levels of both hormones are lower than normal and are believed to be important art of forming relationships and social interaction; could explain why many once orphaned children continue to experience isolation even after many years in loving home environment; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Neglected orphans produce an odd pattern of two bonding hormones.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: PROCEEDINGS OF THE NATIONAL ACADEMY OF SCIENCES

docs.lead_paragraph: More infants were born last year by Caesarean section, more were born prematurely and more were born with a low birth weight in 2004 than in 2003, according to statistics released last week by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The agency's report showed no improvement in the number of women receiving prenatal care, and a slight decline in the number of teenage pregnancies.

headline.main: Premature Births Increase Along With C-Sections

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention publishes annual statistics on pregnancy and birth; Caesarean section, premature birth and low birth weight for babies continued to increase in 2004; possible reasons for some of findings discussed (M)
docs.snippet: More infants were born last year by Caesarean section, more were born prematurely and more were born with a low birth weight in 2004 than in 2003.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 10 million people in the United States are cancer survivors, and their numbers increase daily. Many are considered cured. Some are still in treatment and one day may -- or may not -- be counted among the cured. Others are living with advanced disease. But nearly all have similar needs: A need to know about and cope with the physical and emotional consequences of cancer and its treatment, including current challenges to quality of life and delayed health effects.

headline.main: With Cancer, Treatment Is Only Part of the Picture

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses what cancer survivors should do after initial treatment for cancer has been completed; Dr Sheldon Greenfield, University of California, Irvine, Center for Health Policy Research director, leads study sanctioned by National Academies to develop survivorship care plan; more than 10 million Americans are cancer survivors; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: More than 10 million people in the United States are cancer survivors, and their numbers increase daily. Many are considered cured. Some are still in treatment and one day may -- or may not -- be counted among the cured. Others are living with...

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: NATIONAL ACADEMIES OF THE UNITED STATES

docs.lead_paragraph: Every year, thousands of diabetics have to have part of their legs amputated because of ulceration in their feet, a common complication of the disease. But a new screening tool may help doctors detect changes in the skin of the foot and catch problems before it is too late, researchers say. Diabetics are at increased risk for the ulcers because as the disease progresses, the nerves in their legs and feet often become damaged. Their skin becomes less sensitive, and small injuries like corns or blisters often go unnoticed until they become serious.

headline.main: New Screening May Keep the Feet From Failing

docs.abstract: New Screening test for oxygen levels of skin covering person's foot may help diabetic patients avoid hard to cure foot ulcers, which can lead to amputation; test described; estimated 15 percent of all diabetics with foot wounds end up having amputation; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A new test may help doctors detect changes in the skin of the foot and catch problems caused by diabetes earlier.

docs.lead_paragraph: How do conductors instantly know which musician has let loose with an offending note? The answer may lie in their brains. Researchers have found that conductors process auditory cues better than nonmusicians generally do. The findings were presented at a recent conference of the Society for Neuroscience.

headline.main: Zing Went the Strings of Whose Harp?

docs.abstract: Dr Jonathan H Brudette of Wake Forest University Baptist Medical Center leads study on ability of music conductors to detect directionality of sound; research, which was presented at Society for Neuroscience conference, says that conductors have acute ability to respond to sound in different way than average person
docs.snippet: A conductor's brain may hold the answer to instantly identifying which musician has let loose with an offending note.

docs.lead_paragraph: Flavored cigarettes sold under names like Twista Lime, Midnight Berry and Warm Winter Toffee may be undermining restrictions aimed at stopping tobacco companies from marketing their products to youths, new research from Harvard says. Despite protests by the tobacco industry that it does not seek out the youth market, the researchers, writing in the current issue of Health Affairs, suggest that is exactly what the increasingly popular flavored cigarettes appear meant to do.

headline.main: Harsh Review for Cigarettes With Candy Flavor

docs.abstract: Dr Carrie M Carpenter of Harvard University School of Public Health leads study on flavored cigarettes that finds action by tobacco companies undermines regulations against marketing cigarettes to young people; research is published in journal Health Affairs; tobacco companies hold that flavored cigarettes reflect overall marketplace trend found in many products, not effort to appeal to young smokers; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Flavored cigarettes may be undermining restrictions aimed at stopping tobacco companies from marketing their products to youths.

docs.lead_paragraph: After enduring six miscarriages and undergoing six artificial inseminations and two in vitro fertilizations, Kelly Santos, at the age of 35, was dealt the final blow. ''My doctor told me that I would never have a biological child,'' said Ms. Santos, who lives in Gillette, N.J. The diagnosis was a chromosomal translocation, a mix-up in the arrangement of a few genetic pieces that leads to a high proportion of abnormal embryos and a 90 percent rate of miscarriage.

headline.main: Screening for Abnormal Embryos Offers Couples Hope After Heartbreak

docs.abstract: Preimplantation genetic diagnosis, process in which embryos are tested for genetic disorders and gender prior to implantation in uterus, is giving infertile couples, and particularly those experiencing frequent miscarriages, better opportunity to conceive and carry healthy baby to term; process described; PGD is also being used by parents wanting to have child who can donate matching tissue for sibling with disease; early studies show that PGD lowers number of miscarriages, but experts caution that testing does not guarantee child without genetic problems; photo; drawings (M)
docs.snippet: Preimplantation genetic diagnosis is an increasingly popular way to try to ensure a healthy pregnancy for women who have had difficulty conceiving.

docs.lead_paragraph: When my boyfriend asked me to attend his brother's wedding in 1997, I was a bit nervous: I would be meeting not only Andrew's immediate family but his rather sizable extended family, as well. Coincidentally (or not, my therapist said), I caught a nasty cold a week before the wedding. The day of the big event, the congestion still filled my head, hammering down on my sinuses. I was popping Sudafed like so many red M&Ms, and alternating it with Afrin, a nasal spray. I wanted desperately to be symptom-free.

headline.main: A Wedding, a Cold and a Trip to the Emergency Room

docs.abstract: Laurie Tarkan Cases column describes panic attack she had before family event; discusses medical events that can cause panic attack; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: One woman's efforts to discover what set off her first panic attack.
